conversations.content: The Winds of Paradise: Part One
Vayu was one of the fastest dragons that lived. His gales were so speedy, they cut through the very land itself.
He was a gruff, carefree dragon who never stayed in one place for long. Instead, he traveled the world in order to learn more about his power.
But one day, he accidentally blew off the top of a mountain.
The top of the peak fell into the sea and became a new island.
This made him grumpy, because he knew the waters of this region were home to a very annoying sea dragon.
Though he had not meant to do so, he had created new land in someone else's territory—which was an action no dragon would be fond of.
He wasn't afraid of the conflict that might occur from this action—he just didn't want to argue about it, because that sounded like a pain.
Rather than listen to the sea dragon whine and complain and grumble, Vayu decided to just sink the island before anyone noticed it.
But alas, he had waited too long to act, and a flock of migratory birds had stopped on the new island to rest their weary wings.
He considered scaring them off, but the island was free of predators, and the birds looked quite happy and content with their new home.
Finally, he went to the birds and told them they could stay—but only for a little while. He then spent an entire season on the island waiting for them to go.
During this time, plants began to grow on the island, and other living creatures arrived and began to take up residence.
The situation was clearly untenable, yet Vayu found himself deeply conflicted all the same.
The Winds of Paradise: Part Two
The wind dragon Vayu accidentally created an island—and he knew that if he didn't destroy it, it would anger a local sea dragon.
But Vayu was no monster, and he found himself unable to harm any of the new life that had formed there.
The island boasted singing birds, a dazzling sun, and verdant nature. And after but a single season, he had developed a fondness for it.
He mulled the subject over in his mind, and finally decided to simply leave before the sea dragon found the island. That way, he wouldn't need to do anything at all.
But as he went to leave, a voice suddenly called out to him. ＂You'd better have a good explanation for this, stranger.＂
The voice belonged to the sea dragon who ruled the waters surrounding the island.
Vayu had no choice but to tell the dragon exactly what had transpired. And just as he suspected, the other dragon was enraged, demanding that he get rid of the island at once.
Vayu groaned as the dragon left. He knew full well what he had to do. These waters weren't his to interfere with to begin with.
＂Argh! Just do it, Vayu,＂ he said to himself. ＂You're only getting rid of something that never should have been here.＂ He swung his mighty, wind-clad arm at the island.
The wind made his arm razor-sharp, and he knew the island could not survive even a single blow.
...But then he stopped.
Moments before impact, Vayu turned the gales around his arm into a gentle breeze. He just couldn't bring himself to destroy the island.
When the sea dragon came back, he was more furious than before. But Vayu sat still and silently accepted his endless reprimands.
Finally, the sea dragon decided to destroy the island himself. But as he readied to drown it in a great wave, he looked on it and found that his breath was taken away.
The sun shone. Greenery grew thick. Birds tweeted in a refreshing breeze. It was nothing short of paradise.
＂Well,＂ said the sea dragon, ＂I SUPPOSE I could get used to an island like this in my territory.＂
Vayu smiled to himself, for he knew the other dragon found his creation as beautiful as he did.
Thus the paradise that Vayu created was allowed to remain, and he kept on with his journey. But from time to time, he would sneak back and grant the wind's blessing to the island.
